0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-california-budget-idUSKCN0Z205M	California legislature sends $122.5 billion budget to governor	"
By Rory Carroll
| SAN FRANCISCO
SAN FRANCISCO The California legislature agreed on Wednesday to a $122.5 billion spending plan for the fiscal year starting July 1 and sent it to Governor Jerry Brown
column2: who is expected to sign it. The budget directs $2 billion to the state's rainy day fund
column3: a priority for Brown
column4: a Democrat and fiscal moderate who has warned that an economic downturn could lie ahead for the nation's most populous state. Lower-than-expected income tax revenues in April caught state officials by surprise
column5: and Brown said the state could take in $1.9 billion less than anticipated in taxes over the coming fiscal year. Democratic leaders in the state Senate praised the budget for making investments in the social safety net and early childhood education. The budget included a repeal of the state's maximum family grant rule
column6: which prevents people on welfare from receiving additional public money if they have more children.

column1: Without the rule
column2: households would receive an additional $122 a month for a newborn child. The change is expected to cost the state about $220 million a year. ""Our expenditure plan funds anti-poverty programs
column3: child care and education
column4: said Mark Leno
column5: Democratic state senator and budget chair. ""It also includes resources to combat homelessness
column6: support low-income working families and improve college readiness and enrollment

column1: Republicans and some Democrats complained the spending increase of $6.9 billion from the prior fiscal year set California on a path of billion-dollar deficits down the road. ""Californians deserve a responsible and sustainable state spending plan
column2: said Senate Republican leader Jean Fuller. ""Unfortunately
column3: this record spending budget paves the way for future deficits and increases fees that make living in California even more expensive
column4: she said.

column1: Some of the spending increases were attributed to an increase in the minimum wage and increased benefits for the disabled. In a tweet
column2: Brown said: ""Good work from the state legislature: we're building reserves and investing in CA. Thanks."" Brown has until the end of the month to sign the budget.  (Reporting by Rory Carroll; Editing by Peter Cooney)"

column1: 1	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-guns-idUSKCN0Z11XT	Senators
column2: Trump open to ban on some gun sales after Orlando	"

column1: By Richard Cowan and Susan Cornwell
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. senators signaled on Wednesday a new willingness to consider restrictions on the sale of guns after the Orlando nightclub massacre
column2: with presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump and others in his party ready to discuss limited gun control measures. With Republicans and the National Rifle Association gun lobby under pressure to respond to the worst mass shooting in modern U.S. history
column3: Trump said he would meet with the NRA to discuss ways to block people on terrorism watch or no-fly lists from buying guns. Emotions have run high in Congress since Sunday's mass shooting with Democrats stalling Senate proceedings on Wednesday in a bid to push for tougher gun control legislation. Democratic senators planned to speak on the Senate floor well into Wednesday night. The Senate began discussions on legislation to ban firearm sales to the hundreds of thousands of people on U.S. terrorism watch lists after a gunman who had been on such a list killed 49 people at a gay nightclub on Sunday.But following a full day of wrangling
column4: Senate Democratic leader Harry Reid said that negotiations ""were little more than a smokescreen by Republicans trying to give themselves political cover while they continue to march in lock-step with the NRA's extreme positions.""Reid said there were no Republican proposals ""that come close to attracting Democratic support.""Earlier on Wednesday
column5: Republican Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell urged senators to offer ideas on how to prevent another attack like the one in Orlando. ""I do not believe this was some random act of violence
column6: McConnell said. ""It seems clear this was cold-blooded murder committed by a terrorist who picked his targets with deliberate malice."" On Tuesday
column7: McConnell said that ""nobody wants terrorists to have firearms."" Earlier in the week
column8: some Democrats in the House of Representatives interrupted a moment of silence for the victims
column9: with shouts of ""Where's the bill?"" to protest the Republican-led chamber's refusal to consider tougher gun laws.  If Congress was to pass a gun control measure
column10: it would mark the first time in more than 20 years that lawmakers agreed on how to address the hot-button issue. A ban on semi-automatic assault weapons
column11: such as the one used in Orlando
column12: had gone into effect in 1994 and expired 10 years later.Republicans over the years have blocked gun control measures saying they step on Americans' right to bear arms as guaranteed under the U.S. Constitution. Senator John Cornyn
column14: confirmed that he and Democratic Senator Dianne Feinstein were holding private talks on a possible compromise bill stopping weapons sales to those on watch lists.

column1: OPPORTUNITY CITED
Another Republican
column2: Senator Pat Toomey of Pennsylvania
column3: also is working on a bill that would keep guns from people on watch lists
column4: a gun control group said.Toomey
column5: who is in a possibly difficult re-election bid this year
column6: took to the Senate floor urging compromise.""So there's an obvious opportunity here guys
column7: to work together and find a solution
column10: ""This is not rocket science to figure this out.""A spokeswoman for Toomey
column12: said the senator was seeking bipartisan support for an approach that he had tentatively agreed on with gun control group Everytown for Gun Safety
column13: which is backed by ex-New York Mayor Michael Bloomberg.

column1: Everytown spokeswoman Erika Lamb said the group was encouraged by the discussions but added
column2: ""We are not there yet and our support for any compromise legislation is contingent on support from both Republicans and Democrats.""Toomey's bill would allow the U.S. attorney general to create a new list of ""likely terrorists"" and block any person on the list from buying or selling a gun. If someone was denied a gun
column3: he or she would be entitled to a swift court hearing where the attorney general would have to turn over the evidence against the person.Democrats were dubious. One problem
column4: a Democratic aide said
column5: was that under the proposal officials would just have three days to try to block sales to anyone not already on the new list.Congressional Republicans and the NRA have thwarted previous gun control measures backed by President Barack Obama and other Democrats after other mass shootings
column6: and supporters of new restrictions remained cautious about the moves.""The Cornyn bill is outlandish and is worse than nothing. From what I'm told all of the compromises proposed by Cornyn and Toomey are not at all acceptable
column8: a Democrat of New York.    Feinstein
column9: speaking to reporters following a closed briefing from the Obama administration on the Orlando massacre
column10: held out little hope her talks with Cornyn would bear fruit. ""I don't think it's going to work out
column12: but added she was still engaged in talks.

column1: NRA HAPPY TO MEET WITH TRUMP
Trump said on Twitter he would meet with the NRA ""about not allowing people on the terrorist watch list
column2: or the no-fly list
column3: to buy guns."" His campaign did not specify what he might support legislatively
column4: and a spokeswoman declined to give details about the timing or nature of the meeting.The NRA
column5: a politically influential lobbying group that claims more than 4 million members
column6: said in a statement it was ""happy to meet"" with Trump
column7: whom it endorsed for president on May 20.The group said in a statement that anyone on a terrorism watch list who tries to buy a gun ""should be thoroughly investigated"" by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and any sale to that person delayed
column8: a position the lobby group has long held.Presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton
column9: who has supported gun control efforts
column10: on Monday said she was ""bewildered"" that Republicans in Congress in December had blocked a Democratic effort to restrict gun sales to people on the watch lists.The U.S. government maintains two terrorism watch lists: a no-fly list barring people from flying to and from the United States and a larger one that subjects travelers to greater scrutiny at airports and border crossings.An FBI official said in 2014 there were 64
column11: 000 people on the no-fly list and 800
column12: 000 on the broader list. The Orlando gunman
column14: the U.S.-born son of Afghan immigrants
column15: was on the broader list at one time.NRA Executive Director Chris Cox also voiced backing for legislation offered in December by Cornyn
column16: who proposed to put gun sales on hold for 72 hours for people on watch lists. Critics have said such background checks could take longer to complete.White House spokesman Josh Earnest said it was too soon to tell if Republicans would support ""common sense"" steps like blocking firearm sales to people on the no-fly lists.    (Additional reporting by Susan Heavey and Susan Cornwell; Editing by Howard Goller and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 2	http://reuters.com/article/us-new-york-regulator-idUSKCN0Z2044	New York State Senate confirms Vullo as top financial regulator	"
By Suzanne Barlyn and Rama Venkat Raman
The New York State on Wednesday confirmed Governor Andrew Cuomo's pick to become the state's top financial regulator.The confirmation vote for Maria Vullo
column2: Cuomo's nominee for superintendent of the New York State Department of Financial Services (NYDFS)
column3: was unanimous.Cuomo
column4: a Democrat
column5: nominated Vullo in January. Her appointment is effective immediately. Earlier on Wednesday
column6: the New York Senate Finance Committee held a hearing on Vullo's nomination and recommended that she be confirmed. Last week
column7: the New York Senate's banking and insurance committees also held separate hearings about Vullo.

column1: Vullo
column2: a lawyer who represented banks
column3: described herself during recent state legislative committee meetings as ""pro-business and pro-consumer."" She has been running the NYDFS as its acting superintendent since February.

column1: Vullo will succeed former NYDFS Superintendent Benjamin Lawsky
column2: who left the agency last year.Under Lawsky
column3: NYDFS earned a reputation as an aggressive regulatory body that extracted hefty fines from global banks and other financial institutions.

column1: The regulator
column2: created in 2011 by consolidating the state's banking and insurance agencies
column3: had been in flux since before Vullo's arrival in March.

column1: (Reporting by Suzanne Barlyn in New York and Rama Venkat Raman in Bengaluru; Editing by Andrew Hay)"
3	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-guns-feinstein-idUSKCN0Z12PF	Senator Feinstein doubts talks with Senator Cornyn to produce gun deal	"
WASHINGTON Democratic U.S. Senator Dianne Feinstein said on Wednesday that she doubted talks with the Senate's No. 2 Republican
column2: John Cornyn
column3: would succeed in a deal on legislation to ban gun sales to people on terror watchlists.""I don't think that going to work out
column4: Feinstein told reporters
column5: but added that she was still talking to other lawmakers in an effort to find agreement. She also said she understood that Cornyn had shared her draft legislation with the National Rifle Association.

column1: Now
column2: that would do it
column3: she said
column4: suggesting the gun lobby would reject her proposal.

column1: (Reporting by Susan Cornwell
column2: editing by G Crosse)"

column1: 4	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-idUSKCN0Z12AS	Trump backs surveillance of mosques despite criticism of rhetoric	"
By Emily Stephenson and Amanda Becker
Presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump on Wednesday called for surveillance of mosques as part of U.S. law enforcement efforts to prevent terrorism
column2: and stood by his remarks on banning Muslim immigrants
column3: which others in his party have criticized.Trump repeated his call for a temporary ban on the entry of Muslims into the United States after a U.S.-born Muslim
column4: the son of Afghan immigrants
column5: fatally shot 49 people at a gay nightclub in Orlando early on Sunday.The New York real estate developer said that while the Florida gunman was born in the United States
column6: ""his parents weren't and his ideas weren't born here."" ""We have to maybe check
column8: the mosques and we have to check other places because this is a problem that
column10: it's going to eat our country alive
column11: Trump said at a rally in Atlanta.Trump had called for surveillance of mosques in November
column12: as well as a database of Syrian refugees entering the United States.The Orlando gunman
column14: is believed by authorities to have acted alone
column15: inspired by radical ideology he was exposed to over the internet.

column1: Any kind of extremism and violence is not preached in American mosques
column2: said Ibrahim Hooper
column3: communications director for the Council on American-Islamic Relations. ""In fact
column4: research has shown that mosques are a moderating influence on individuals who attend.""Prominent Republicans this week distanced themselves from Trump's comments about Muslims. House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan said on Tuesday he did not think a ban on the entry of Muslims was in U.S. interests. Senator Lindsey Graham of South Carolina
column5: who ran against Trump for the Republican nomination and has been a fierce critic since
column6: said that he was ""unnerved"" by Trump's response.

column1: Hillary Clinton
column2: the presumptive Democratic nominee
column3: said on Wednesday that Trump's rhetoric had grown ""even more inflammatory"" in recent days. She said the United States counts on Muslim communities in the U.S. and partners in majority-Muslim countries to help fight terrorism.""Not one of Donald Trump's reckless ideas would have saved a single life in Orlando
column4: Clinton said at an event for U.S. military families in Virginia.Trump on Monday proposed that the United States suspend immigration from areas of the world where there is ""a proven history of terrorism against the United States
column5: Europe or our allies until we fully understand how to end these threats."" He also said radical Muslims were entering the country amid a flood of refugees and ""trying to take over our children.""

column1: Trump's hard-line proposals on immigration have contributed to his popularity among some conservative voters. But they have also triggered condemnation from minority and human rights activists and his political opponents
column2: many of whom have called his rhetoric racist.The New York businessman also said in Atlanta he would meet North Korean leader Kim Jong Un if he came to the United States
column3: and he dismissed the controversy he caused in May when he said in a Reuters interview he would be willing to speak to Kim.""If he came here
column4: I'd accept him. But I wouldn't give a state dinner like we do for China and all these other people  that rip us off
column5: Trump said. (Reporting by Emily Stephenson and Amanda Becker; Editing by Will Dunham and Leslie Adler)"

column1: 5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-clinton-tax-idUSKCN0Z12F4	Clinton would use executive action to end tax loophole: USA Today	"
WASHINGTON U.S. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton said
column2: if elected
column3: she would use executive action to end a tax loophole for wealthy Americans
column4: according to an interview with USA Today on Wednesday.Clinton said that if Congress did not act
column5: she would ask the Treasury Department to use its authority to end the tax advantage
column6: known as the carried interest loophole
column7: which allows hedge-fund managers to pay a lower rate than other taxpayers by counting their income as investment income.

column1: (Writing by Eric Beech; Editing by Eric Walsh)"
6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-obama-michelle-idUSKCN0Z12EC	Michelle Obama
column2: daughters to visit Liberia
column3: Morocco
column4: Spain: White House	"

column1: WASHINGTON Michelle Obama will travel to Liberia
column2: Morocco and Spain with her teen daughters Malia and Sasha at the end of June to promote education for girls
column3: one of her signature issues as the first lady of the United States
column4: the White House said on Wednesday.In Liberia
column5: Obama will visit a Peace Corps training center in Kakata and a school in Unification Town to talk to young women about barriers they face to staying in school. She will be joined by Liberian President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf
column6: the White House said.Obama will be joined by actor Meryl Streep in Morocco on June 28 and 29 to talk about commitments made by the U.S. government and the Kingdom of Morocco to help girls go to school.

column1: On June 30
column2: Obama will wrap up the trip by giving a speech in Madrid about her ""Let Girls Learn"" global initiative
column3: a push to harness government and private sector resources to promote education for girls
column4: the White House said.

column1: (Reporting by Roberta Rampton; Editing by Tom Brown)"
7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-israel-defense-idUSKCN0Z129Q	U.S. signals accommodation of Israeli terms on defense aid	"
By Matt Spetalnick and Dan Williams
| WASHINGTON/HERZLIYA
column2: Israel

column1: WASHINGTON/HERZLIYA
column2: Israel The Obama administration is prepared to incorporate missile defense funds in a new long-term agreement on military aid for Israel
column3: a U.S. official said on Wednesday
column4: accommodating in principle a key request by its ally in the yet-unresolved talks.Disputes over the scope and fine print of the memorandum of understanding (MOU) have clouded already difficult ties between Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and U.S. President Barack Obama during the latter's final months in office.The current MOU
column5: signed in 2007 and due to expire in 2018
column6: gave Israel around $30 billion in so-called foreign military financing. Israel has been seeking around $10 billion more for the next decade and that money be earmarked for missile defense projects that were hitherto funded ad hoc by the U.S. Congress.U.S. negotiators previously proposed a total of $3.5 billion to $3.7 billion annually for Israel under the new MOU
column7: but did not say whether this might include missile defense funds. A senior U.S. official was more forthcoming on Wednesday.""We are prepared to make an unprecedented multi-year missile defense commitment as part of a new memorandum of understanding with Israel on military assistance
column11: which would amount to billions of dollars over 10 years
column12: would be the first long-term pledge on missile defense support to Israel
column13: affording Israel robust support for its missile defense
column14: as well as predictability and facilitating long-term planning.""U.S. lawmakers have in recent years given Israel up to $600 million in annual discretionary funds for missile defense
column15: well beyond the $150 million requested by the Obama administration.

column1: On Tuesday
column2: the White House opposed a proposal to include $600 million for Israeli missile defense to an appropriations bill for the fiscal year starting on Oct. 1.INTERNAL DEBATE

column1: Netanyahu came out with a rare statement on the MOU talks
column2: in the face of Israeli opposition accusations that he is endangering American largesse by feuding with Obama over Iran's nuclear program and Palestinian peace talks.Netanyahu's office said on Twitter that the White House's move on Tuesday was part of an ""internal debate"" with Congress about supplementary missile defense funding for Israel.""There has been no cut in American assistance
column3: it tweeted. ""Prime Minister Netanyahu is working to anchor this supplement as part of the discussions on the assistance agreement for the next ten years. Not only will security assistance for missile defense not be cut
column4: it will be increased.""However
column7: made clear agreement was not a given. Israeli officials have hinted that
column9: they might await the next U.S. president in hope of getting a better MOU.

column1: Netanyahu's government was working to wrap up the talks with the Obama administration
column2: Nagel told reporters. But he added: ""When we conclude that we have arrived at the final (U.S.) offer
column3: we will decide if we want it or not."" Another sticking point has been a U.S. demand to reduce the amount of aid money - now 26.3 percent - that Israel can spend on its own military industries rather than on American products. Visiting Israel for strategic talks
column4: U.S. Deputy Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Wednesday said it had received $8.5 million a day from the Obama administration in defense aid.In a speech to the annual Herzliya Conference
column5: Blinken did not give details on the MOU talks
column6: but he said Washington was ready to give Israel ""the largest single pledge of military assistance from the United States to any country in our history
column7: cementing an unparalleled security relationship all the way to 2029"".  (Additional reporting by Patricia Zengerle in Washington; Writing by Dan Williams; Editing by Larry King)"

column1: 8	http://reuters.com/article/us-florida-shooting-guns-nra-idUSKCN0Z123H	Sales to people on terrorism watch lists should be delayed: NRA	"
WASHINGTON The National Rifle Association said on Wednesday it stood by its position on terrorism watch lists and access to firearms
column2: saying sales to potential buyers who are on the lists should be delayed while they are investigated by the FBI.In a statement
column3: the gun lobbying group said it welcomed a meeting with Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump. It also said protections needed to be put in place to allow people wrongfully put on a terrorism watch list to be removed.

column1: (Reporting by Washington newsroom; Editing by Mohammad Zargham and Lisa Von Ahn)"
9	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-sanders-idUSKCN0Z126B	Sanders not ending campaign in Thursday's video speech: spokesman	"
By John Whitesides
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Bernie Sanders does not plan to suspend his campaign and endorse presumptive Democratic presidential nominee Hillary Clinton in a video speech to supporters on Thursday
column2: focusing instead on ways to pursue his policy agenda and reform goals
column3: a spokesman said.Sanders
column4: who has resisted pressure to exit the race and back Clinton in a show of party unity since she clinched the Democratic nomination last week
column5: will address supporters nationwide on a video live stream on Thursday night.That raised expectations Sanders might formally pull the plug on his campaign. But spokesman Michael Briggs said on Wednesday the speech will focus on how Sanders' supporters can keep the fight alive on priorities such as raising the minimum wage and reducing the influence of big money in politics.""Tomorrow night
column8: Briggs said of the campaign. ""We're working our way through that
column9: how to go forward on that front. This message to supporters is going to be a lot broader than that.""Sanders
column11: has promised to continue his campaign to next month's Democratic nominating convention in Philadelphia as leverage to force concessions from Clinton on his policy goals and on reforms he seeks in the Democratic Party's nominating process.

column1: Since Clinton secured enough delegates for the nomination last week
column2: however
column3: Sanders has laid off some campaign staff
column4: stopped holding rallies and dropped plans to court unbound delegates in an unspoken acknowledgment that the former secretary of state will be the nominee.""He knows how to count
column5: Briggs said.Sanders and Clinton met in a downtown Washington hotel for more than 90 minutes on Tuesday night to search for common ground after she won the final nominating contest in their sometimes bitter primary campaign.

column1: In similarly worded statements
column2: both camps described the meeting as ""positive"" and said the two discussed their shared goal of defeating presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump in the Nov. 8 election.Sanders was back home in Burlington
column3: Vermont
column4: on Wednesday to prepare his speech and consider how to keep pressuring Clinton to back issues like raising the minimum wage and fighting climate change.

column1: He also has demanded changes to the party nominating process
column2: including replacing the Democratic National Committee leadership and eliminating superdelegates
column3: who are unelected and are free to support any candidate.The Sanders camp has pushed for a commitment to hold votes at the convention on some of those platform issues and on changing party nominating rules.""We see the convention as a serious opportunity for a serious discussion about a lot of these issues. We hope the Democratic Party establishment can figure out a way to open its arms and welcome into the party fold the people who have been excited by Bernie's campaign
column4: Briggs said. (Editing by Dan Grebler)"
